awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Developing a New Large-Scale Battery Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this this Partnerships for Innovation – Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project will be the availability of a low-cost stationary battery. Low-cost energy storage will accelerate the adoption of intermittent renewable energy. The small footprint of this battery will enable large-scale energy storage in previously inaccessible locations.  Students will be trained in advanced industrial research and entrepreneurial skills. 

The proposed project will develop a battery with potentially an order of magnitude improvement in volumetric energy density over commercial conventional flow battery systems. This improvement is possible with a new approach in which energy is stored in solid particles, and electrical power is delivered through dissolved species in organic electrolyte. To advance translation, advances are needed in engineering the energy storage chemical reaction processes, optimizing the dissolved chemical species needed to deliver power, and designing a membrane with high conductivity but low crossover of the dissolved chemical species. Furthermore, this project will address the systems engineering and scaling challenges associated with integration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a battery with an order of magnitude improvement in volumetric energy density over commercial conventional flow battery systems. This improvement was possible because the battery technology was based on a new approach where energy was stored in solid particles, and electrical power was delivered through dissolved species in organic electrolyte. To move the technology forward, advances were pursued in the chemical reactor which contained the solid particles, the selective membrane used in the flow cell, the redox shuttles, and integration of the combined system. Knowledge gained through the efforts in this project were disseminated via peer reviewed publications. This project also generated intellectual property, including two nonprovisional patents submitted as a result of the research.

 

Another goal of this project is training students to receive advanced skills in energy-related research and entrepreneurial skills. The graduate students contributing to this project were involved in all research and development activities. Through this collaborative project, the students were able to learn about the different disciplinary and multidisciplinary aspects of this research including new techniques in polymer synthesis and processing, electrochemical characterization, membrane characterization, reactor design, and battery design and characterization. Graduate students also participated in opportunities for entrepreneurial training through I-CORPS programming. Student participants have gone on to careers in industry, including two working in battery development related roles and one with a startup company.

 

This project contributed primarily to the discipline of battery research. More specifically, the project developed and improved understanding of a high energy nonaqueous flow battery system. Beyond high energy density batteries, the results were translatable to advancing multiple other disciplines. The development of the membrane material was relevant to polymer science and understanding transport in soft materials. The chemical reaction system was also unique, using dissolved species to drive chemical reactions for battery electrode materials.

 

With regards to broader impacts, the United States, and the world, needs low cost and flexible stationary energy storage. Successful production of low cost, large scale stationary energy storage will enable mitigation of intermittent renewable power generation which is increasingly being installed to power our lives. Batteries can enable intermittent power to be dispatchable, and relative to other options are among the best with regards to fast startup time and geographic flexibility. The order-of-magnitude increase in energy density, relative to other flow batteries, in this work, reduces parasitic losses (i.e., pumping or self-discharge), safety risks, environmental impacts, and footprint, which enables installation in new space-constrained locations. These competitive advantages suggest the battery in this project could have significant market penetration when deployed commercially, providing a competitive advantage to infrastructure in the United States.

 


Last Modified: 03/17/2025
Modified by: Gary Koenig
